ANNUAL BONUS INCENTIVES
FOR FACTORY WORKERS


    2. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Finance if he will request factory owners to set aside a certain percentage from the factory's annual profits so that the amount set aside can be given to workers as annual bonus incentives.

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, section 46 (1) of the Employment Act, 1968, (No. 17 of 1968) already provides that the contract of service or collective agreement between an employer and his employees may contain a provision for the payment of an amount not exceeding the equivalent of one month's wages of an employee as bonus or ex gratia payment. In addition, section 46 (2) of the Act states that nothing in subsection (1) of section 46 shall be construed as preventing an employer at his discretion from paying as bonus or ex gratia payment an amount that exceeds the equivalent of one month's wages as an incentive to his employees to increase their productivity or as a reward for their services. Bonus up to one month's salary is now therefore a negotiable

Column: 1159

item between employer and employee. And it is not necessary to request factory owners to set aside a certain percentage from the factory's annual profits to be given as an annual bonus incentive. In fact, the wise factory owner will also usually make an allowance for incentive or reward bonus in his calculations without being told to do so, although some timely urging on the part of the unions always helps.

    I have already stated in the debate on the Government financial policy that when the effects of the accelerated military run-down have been clearly overcome, we shall have to consider how best workers should be enabled to share in any increased profits where they result from increased productivity or from a general expansion of the economy. One of the ways would be to make bonus payments negotiable beyond the present limitation of one month's salary. This has been legislated for in certain countries and is the practice in others. In our own situation, however, this could be against our main policy of attracting middle technology industries. We want more capital intensive high skills and high value added industries in Singapore. They come mainly from the Western industrial countries where the payment of bonus is not a practice. West European and American companies prefer to pay higher wages rather than bonuses. They want concealed benefits reduced to a minimum so that they know where they stand from year to year. This philosophy treats profits as the result of efficient management, and losses as the result of the ineffective use of expensive labour, since all employers pay their workers the same rate for the job. We shall make a decision after carefully weighing the pros and cons. Our decision must advance our purpose, namely, to raise the living standard of Singapore workers through higher skills and higher productivity.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, will the Minister for Finance consider requesting established factories which have over the years made good profits to make ex gratia payments to their employees?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: I have already stated that there is in the law a provision for unions to take this up. Although bonus is not negotiable beyond one month, I said that some timely urging on the part of the unions always helps in making payments beyond what may have been negotiated.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, it may be true that such practice may be going on. But I am told that many employers make use of the Employment Act as a lever in their negotiations with unions on the question of bonus.

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have nothing to add to what I have said. The position is that the employers will negotiate on bonus payments up to one month's wages in their collective agreements. Beyond one month, this is at present discretionary.

    Dr Augustine H. H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Minister for Finance not think that foreign investors should do in Singapore what the Singaporeans do in respect of bonus payments? In other words, should they not try to adopt a simple practice like that?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, that is a philosophy which we cannot adopt in all cases. For example, Singaporeans have not carried out industrialisation previously, and if you apply that very simple philosophy to what Singaporeans have been doing in the past, then there would be no industrialisation. In the same way I do not think that the fact that some companies pay bonuses means that Western industrialised companies should do the same.

    Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, does the Minister for Finance realise that he has thrown a red herring into the whole issue?

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Finance has mentioned just now the word "discretion" used by employers in respect of bonus payments. Is he or is he not aware that a good number of commercial firms make good profits and the Employment Act prevents the unions from asking for better bonus payments?

Column: 1161



    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, I am aware of the provisions of the law and I am aware that some companies make profits and some companies quote the provisions of the Employment Act. I have already said that this is a matter which is being very carefully considered. There are pros and cons and a decision will be made after a study of all the factors. Whether we should legislate for bonus payments, or whether we should encourage companies so that they consolidate bonus payments into wages and then stimulate higher productivity, is a very controversial matter and requires very careful consideration.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Sir, is the Minister aware that some of the American firms pay bonus?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Yes, I am aware.

ILLEGAL IMMIGRATION
(Control measures)


    3. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Home Affairs how many illegal immigrants were detained during the period 1st January to 28th February, 1971; and what plans he has to stop the social and security threat posed by the unceasing inflow of such persons.

    The Minister for Home Affairs (Prof. Wong Lin Ken): Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of illegal immigrants detained during the period 1st January, 1971, to the 28th February, 1971, is exactly 119.

    The control of illegal entry into Singapore is under the constant attention of the Immigration Department. However, a fully effective air, sea and land control system to prevent illegal immigration entails a sizable increase in expense and manpower. Concerted action is being taken by the Police and Immigration Departments to guard the Singapore coast-line against acts of illegal entry. Special police constables are constantly being deployed around certain beaches as shore patrols, while the Marine Police patrol boats cover the coastal waters. In addition, spot checks and investigations and raids are

Column: 1162

conducted by the Immigration Department and the Police from time to time to detect illegal immigrants.

    When illegal immigrants are arrested, action is taken forthwith against them under the Immigration (Amendment) Act, 1970. Traffickers of illegal immigrants are severely dealt with under the Act.

    The inflow of illegal immigrants continues. However, the number of immigrants entering Singapore illegally does not constitute a social threat. As regards security, the position is well under control and there is no threat to our security.

    Mr Ang Nam Piau (Thomson)(In Mandarin): Sir, can the Minister for Home Affairs say from what countries most of the illegal immigrants come?

    Prof. Wong Lin Ken: Sir, I cannot give the actual number of illegal immigrants from any particular country. But most of them come from Indonesia and Malaysia.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, will the Minister be kind enough to give the number of illegal immigrants who were detained during the period as asked for in this question?

    Prof. Wong Lin Ken: I thought I had given the figure earlier. The number of illegal immigrants detained during the period is exactly 119.

    If the Member for Whampoa knows of any particular deficiencies in the service conditions, perhaps he will be good enough to let us know what these are and I shall be very grateful and make the necessary amendments.

    There was also some criticism by the Member for Telok Blangah of the manner in which personnel relations were being handled in my Ministry. The suggestion was that it was desirable to emulate the private sector in their personnel management practices and that we should introduce more modern management techniques. Like all institutions, there is room for improvement in our Ministry and we shall, of course, try our best to improve our techniques. In fact, my officers have already started courses in modern management techniques in the Staff Training Institute, and we shall try to include in them personnel management courses. At the same time, I think our officers are doing very well, in spite of the shortage that we have in the General Administrative Service, in tackling the various problems that are coming in from the Ministries. I think it is a

Column: 1164

comparatively less complex matter to be the personnel manager of a firm with 10, 15, 100 or even 500 workers than to be in charge of a Government Ministry where the workers are counted in tens of thousands. Even if you consider the private sector, when you come to companies like General Motors or Imperial Chemical Industries, I think you will find that the need for uniformity in treatment, in service conditions and any other company practices are not dissimilar to those in the Government Ministries, and that the decisions have to be consistent, and if you have a precedent, you must be prepared to apply that precedent to all other employees in the company.

    There was also a comment that the grievances of the various civil service organisations were not being handled expeditiously. It was stated that there was only one Executive Officer to deal with the daily-rated workers. This is certainly not correct. If the Member will look at the Government Directory, he will see that, apart from the Permanent Secretary, the Deputy Secretary is also in charge of service conditions, and there is an Assistant Secretary dealing specifically with daily-rated workers, although a Higher Executive Officer also handles them.

    With regard to the claims of grievances of workers, I believe that last year we handled the problems of the technical services, as a result of which a new scheme of service conditions was implemented in October last year. I hope this gives some satisfaction at least to the Member for Telok Blangah.

    As for the other services, I think we have already stated that as far as education is concerned, we are ready to proceed with further discussions with the teachers after the budget session. The Cabinet has appointed a review committee to deal with the Police grievances, and we will follow in short order with the Fire Brigade, and the Customs and Immigration services, while in the Ministry of Finance itself we are looking into the clerical services scheme. That is all I have to add at this stage.

up of a consumers' association in order to protect the interest of the consumers, whereas the Minister himself was not too keen to help set it up. Who is actually right? I would like the Minister or his Minister of State to clarify.

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, there was no misunderstanding on the setting up of a consumers' association. At a later stage I made it quite clear that we would be prepared to help this consumers' association if they require assistance, either in the matter of statistics or prices which our inspectors can investigate, or in the matter of quality control which the Singapore institute of Standards and Industrial Research will help to test. The answer, therefore, to the first question - in what way can we help? - is to help the consumers' association help themselves. I think I made it quite clear that I would not be inclined to advocate price control, because this would be detrimental to further supplies coming forward and would not be a solution, but we will, of course, take cognisance of any increase in prices, and if there are possibilities of lowering prices by an increase in imports from cheaper sources, we will try our best to encourage this.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): In view of the detailed explanation given by the Minister and my hope that he will take practical measures to carry out his suggestions, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Hon. Members: Hear, hear!

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Mr Speaker, Sir, the post of Senior Economist in the Economic Section has not been filled. This post was at one time known as the Director of Projects in the Economic Planning Unit and was converted to that of Senior Economist in 1969. It is not expected to fill this particular post easily. Our practice has been to try to fill it by posting from the Administrative Service.

    I should clarify the position that in our Economic Section there is not just one such post. In fact, a Deputy Secretary is in charge of the whole function of economic research, and there are quite a number of economists as well as engineers and others in our Economic Section. We have some difficulty in getting more economists to come forward, and we shall be glad if the Member for Whampoa can introduce any additional economists to us. What we have been trying to do is to get the Economic Research Centre of the University of Singapore to co-operate with us by seconding some personnel. They have, in fact, done so in the past. They have agreed to make available, on an overall supervisory basis a senior economist for our purposes.

May I know from the Minister for Finance why he has not started a scholarship scheme or a fellowship scheme to send bright people abroad, and to maintain a corps of very competent top-grade economists who are well trained? Sir, we cannot just go on the present makeshift basis whereby we have people do an analysis that such and such a thing went up by so many percentage points or went down by so

many percentage points. They should make a real analysis.

When these products, i.e., the first derivatives, come back, they train other people, and we then get the second derivatives, because very few people ever measure up to the qualities of their teachers.

and the Minister just brushed it aside and said, "Well, money is not the only thing that matters. What is two or four increments?", and so on. But to a young man starting out on a career, a few increments can make a great deal of difference.

    Mr Conceicao: Sir, yesterday reference was made in this House to the upgrading of civil servants in terms of salary scales. Reference was also made to the academic qualifications of civil servants. My concern is whether action is being taken to improve the performance of our civil servants.

He has given adequate details in his speech at the official opening of this institute. I note that the courses will not only benefit administrative officers but also other subordinate categories of staff who will be included in this training scheme. Moreover, by having a corps of full-time

Column: 1171

staff, it will be more convenient and more easily manageable for evaluation of the effects of such courses to be made and for appropriate follow-up action to be organised. I hope also that courses will be conducted in creative learning-teaching situations without too much subscription to chalk and talk and rows of civil servants listening to the guru who may happen to be a senior officer handing it out to those who sit at his feet.

    I do not notice that even under O. C. A. R, there are votes for audiovisual equipment. I hope that when courses are given, every appropriate resort will be made to devices in terms of the format of the course as well as in terms of equipment, which will facilitate training and result in civil servants considering it a worth-while and interesting endeavour to have participated in this training.

    Finally, Sir, I would also like to know what is meant by "on-the-job training". If it is considered that on-the-job training is important to supplement on-course training, what is being done to formalise or institutionalise such procedures, apart from flinging the Instruction Manual at a new incumbent?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Mr Speaker, Sir, the courses which are being run have been mentioned in my speech to which the Member for Katong has referred. In 1971 we will begin with an intermediate course in Management and Public Administration for administrative officers, and go on to advanced courses in Management and Public Administration for more senior administrative officers. We will induct and provide intermediate courses for officers in the General Executive and Clerical Services. We will have courses for Personal Assistants, Receptionists, Telephone Operators, and Counter Clerks. We have courses in the Outward Bound School and in the National Youth Leadership Training Institute for officers in supervisory positions. And we will have Language courses for officers required to pass language examinations.

    The instructors for the courses will come from various sources. I think the major part will be drawn from the civil servants themselves, but for the intermediate, advanced and induction courses, experienced and senior civil servants, together with officers from statutory boards, will give lectures. But we will also invite qualified persons from the private sector and institutions such as the University of Singapore, Nanyang University, the Singapore Institute of Management, and other bodies to give courses in their fields of specialisation, especially in relation to management practices and techniques which have been mentioned by Members in relation to the civil service.

    The allowances which will be paid to instructors and lecturers vary according to the level of instruction and nature of the courses. Generally, I think the intermediate and advanced course instructors will be paid up to $25 an hour, while in the case of language instruction there are various rates; maybe the Adult Education Board scale of fees will be adopted. These vary from $4 to $10 an hour. Staff members of the institute who also give lectures will not be paid any fee. There will be some permanent members, but in view of the very wide field that we are going to cover, it will not be possible for us to have full-time staff lecturers in all the various courses that we want.

    In regard to equipment, the Member for Katong is quite right - at the moment we have no audio-visual equipment, but we hope that as we go on this can be provided. It is always possible, of course, to get it on loan from the various organisations. Until the need is proved, I do not think we should go immediately into the purchase of this equipment.

    With regard to what is meant by on-the-job training, it means that, instead of just getting new recruits into the administrative service thrown into the jobs, as was the case before, we will provide a more supervised kind of on-the-job training. We have, therefore, in the Ministry of Finance created a

Column: 1173

Deputy Secretary's post and the officer will be in charge of all matters relating to training as well as supervision.
